config.question: Why did the Haymarket Riot weaken the labor movement?

choices.content: It linked labor and anarchism in the public mind.
The riot led to the death of numerous laborers.
It led to the creation of laws prohibiting labor unions.
The riot was ultimately unsuccessful in reaching its demands.

answer_3.response: While the authorities never discovered who threw the bomb in Haymarket Square, the riot that followed left seven police officers dead and more than 60 wounded. Many Americans—not just business leaders—demanded action against labor “radicalism.” Cities strengthened their police forces and armories. Eight Chicago anarchists were convicted of murder. Although there was no evidence of their guilt, four were hanged, one committed suicide, and three remained in jail until the governor pardoned them in 1893. Linking labor and anarchism in the public mind, the Haymarket Riot weakened the labor movement because the public associated labor with anarchism
